sections.name: Noppera-Bo Grunt
sections.text: Noppera-bo grunts lack the social graces necessary to fully disguise themselves with another person's face.

sources.name: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was

link.name: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was pg. 84
link.alt: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was pg. 84

sections.name: Noppera-Bo
Consummate Professionals
sections.text: While the typical noppera-bo is cruel and revels in the act of frightening or tormenting humanoid creatures, not all of them wallow in evil. Neutral noppera-bos tend to be pranksters who use their abilities to trick and tease, while the rare good nopperabos instead use their abilities to honor and idolize those they admire while focusing their own time on developing their skills at art or crafting.

sources.name: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was

link.name: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was pg. 84
link.alt: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was pg. 84

sections.name: Noppera-Bo Origins
sections.text: There are many theories on the origins of noppera-bos—from tanuki whose change shape ability went wrong, to humanoids who were warped by curses, to naturally spawning yokai. Some even theorize this condition is a transmissible curse like lycanthropy. Most noppera-bos don't recall their origins, and are often more interested in pretending to be someone else entirely.

sources.name: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was

link.name: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was pg. 84
link.alt: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was pg. 84

sections.text: Noppera-bos appear to be regular humans from behind, and might even resemble someone you know, until they turn to reveal a featureless face.

traits.name: Uncommon
traits.text: Something of uncommon rarity requires special training or comes from a particular culture or part of the world. Some character choices give access to uncommon options, and the GM can choose to allow access for anyone. Less is known about uncommon creatures than common creatures. They typically can't be summoned. The DC of Recall Knowledge checks related to these creature is increased by 2.

traits.name: Chaotic
traits.text: Chaotic effects often manipulate energy from chaos-aligned Outer Planes and are anathema to lawful divine servants or divine servants of lawful deities. A creature with this trait is chaotic in alignment.

traits.name: Evil
traits.text: Evil effects often manipulate energy from evil-aligned Outer Planes and are antithetical to good divine servants or divine servants of good deities. A creature with this trait is evil in alignment.

traits.name: Aberration
traits.text: Aberrations are creatures from beyond the planes or corruptions of the natural order.

sources.name: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was

link.name: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was pg. 84
link.alt: Pathfinder #196: The Summer That Never Was pg. 84

interaction_abilities.name: No Face
interaction_abilities.text: Noppera-bos have no sense of vision, but their sense of hearing is precise. They don't breathe and are immune to effects that require breathing. They gain sustenance by absorbing fluids through their skin—traditionally by immersing their hands or faceless head into the fluid to “drink” through osmosis; they can also benefit from consumables, such as potions or elixirs, in this way.

automatic_abilities.name: Sensitive Hearing
automatic_abilities.text: As long as a noppera-bo is deafened, they are slowed 1.

traits.name: Thrown
traits.text: You can throw this weapon as a ranged attack, and it is a ranged weapon when thrown. A thrown weapon adds your Strength modifier to damage just like a melee weapon does. When this trait appears on a melee weapon, it also includes the range increment. Ranged weapons with this trait use the range increment specified in the weapon’s Range entry.

ability.name: Impersonate Shape

traits.name: Concentrate
traits.text: An action with this trait requires a degree of mental concentration and discipline.

traits.name: Occult
traits.text: This magic comes from the occult tradition, calling upon bizarre and ephemeral mysteries. Anything with this trait is magical.

traits.name: Polymorph
traits.text:
These effects transform the target into a new form. A target can't be under the effect of more than one polymorph effect at a time. If it comes under the effect of a second polymorph effect, the second polymorph effect attempts to counteract the first. If it succeeds, it takes effect, and if it fails, the spell has no effect on that target. Any Strikes specifically granted by a polymorph effect are magical. Unless otherwise stated, polymorph spells don't allow the target to take on the appearance of a specific individual creature, but rather just a generic creature of a general type or ancestry.  
  
 If you take on a battle form with a polymorph spell, the special statistics can be adjusted only by circumstance bonuses, status bonuses, and penalties. Unless otherwise noted, the battle form prevents you from casting spells, speaking, and using most manipulate actions that require hands. (If there's doubt about whether you can use an action, the GM decides.) Your gear is absorbed into you; the constant abilities of your gear still function, but you can't activate any items.

traits.name: Transmutation
traits.text: Effects and magic items with this trait are associated with the transmutation school of magic, typically changing something’s form.

ability.text: The noppera-bo grunt changes into a faceless version of a Small or Medium humanoid they've touched during the last 24 hours. While transformed and their face is covered, the grunt gains a +2 circumstance bonus to Impersonate that creature. The noppera-bo grunt can change back by using this ability again.
